reviewText:
Frankenstein: Master of Death is the newest title from JetDogs to make it to Steam and is a nice addition to the hidden object catalog here.  An alternate take on the Frankenstein story, the premise is interesting albeit a bit hokey at the same time.  Granted, HOGs are not known for their great storylines as they're often just a base to build a game upon, but that's usually enough for me.  The time period offers us an amazing setting for gorgeously drawn backgrounds and artwork, my favorite aspect of these games.

Keys, keys and more keys.  A good portion of the game involves finding different keys for lock boxes, doors, and just about everything else.  Some open puzzles while others give access to new rooms and areas of the map.  While it gets rather tiresome opening door after box after door, once I realized that's basically the shtick of the gameplay I was able to sit back and enjoy it for what it is.  Fortunately, there are plenty of puzzles to play through, but nothing too difficult or mind bending. The hidden object scenes are interesting in that many include mini-puzzles within them as well, a neat addition that you don't see very often.  As for the scenes themselves, they're nicely drawn with no deceptively hidden items, just challenging enough to keep your eyes sharp.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: Got this game as a gift (thanks!)

This is my first experience with a JetDogs HOG. Definitely not as good as Artifex Mundi, but still a HOG worth playing.

This HOG was somewhat more inventory oriented than others on Steam. Some items have multiple uses. A recurring theme is finding particularly shaped keys to open doors or containers (over a dozen).

The hidden object scenes are quite easy compared to most HOGs. The scenes are not very cluttered and the objects are placed normally rather than being hidden in clever but often unintuitive ways as many HOGs like to do.

A single playthrough takes only about 3 hours.

Pros:
* Nice static art
* Some scenes have some animations
* Hidden Object Scenes have many mini puzzles
* Hidden Object Scenes not too difficult
* Puzzles are straightforward/easy (there is a sliding 9-puzzle, though, that I'm not a fan of)
* Good cutscenes
* Good voice acting
* All achievements can be earned in a single playthrough (don't use hints or skip anything, and ensure that Advanced Mode is set in Options before starting).

Cons:
* 3D characters are a bit ugly
* Monster and some character animation is silly looking
* Somewhat weak writing (though not terrible for a HOG)
* Crude use of sound effects. Music is sometimes annoying.
* Some illogic (e.g. can cut chains but not thin bars with hacksaw)
* No replayability features (scenes not random, can't replay scenes).
* Crashed once during gameplay (progress auto-saves), once on startup, and every time on exit
* Some achievements are buggy (if you don't earn them the first time around, you may have to purge your profile data to earn them). I still haven't unlocked 2 of them despite seemingly meeting the conditions, but I haven't tried the data purge trick yet.

reviewText:
A hidden object game with a good storyline, beautiful graphics, and fully animated and voice-acted cutscenes.
A nice addition to the genre here is that there is both an expert and easy mode, with the easy mode allowing you to skip most of the hidden object puzzles and just focusing on the adventure item collecting/combining parts.
There is also a hint button on a timer, which helps you find the next screen to work on. Since this is a rather large game where you have to backtrack a lot, this comes in really helpful as a hint always works on a per-screen basis: once you can figure out where to go next, you can stop using it.

The voice acting is for the most part pretty good, except for the (few) lines voiced by the player character. Not sure what went wrong there, they sound too far away and don't fit the otherwise high quality design of the game.

Recommended for anyone who likes hidden object games, although parents of *very* young players should keep in mind the game may be a bit scary for them.

reviewText:
Frankenstein: Master of Death is a thoroughly average and unremarkable HOPA (Hidden Object Puzzle Adventure game, in which there is a mix of exploring rooms to gather items, mini-game puzzles, and hidden object scenes). While I think the developers did well in crafting a spooky atmosphere with the game's ~30 beautiful rooms (or scenes), the voice acting isn't very good (the protagonist's voice is especially awful), and the story is poor.

In fact, the storyline goes as follows: The protagonist, a friend of scientist Frankenstein, is tasked to stop Frankenstein's  monster, which Frankenstein greatly regrets creating. The protagonist then discovers that an evil man (an associate of Frankenstein) has a grand scheme to control this monster, and you basically go from scene to scene trying to stop this evil man. Ridiculous events occur in which this evil man slips from your grasp over and over. After awhile, I found myself not caring about what was going to happen next.

I play many HOPAs, and I finished Frankenstein: Master of Death in under 2 hours on Expert mode. This game simply wasn't a cost efficient purchase for me, which I could look beyond if the game had a memorable story and/or characters, which it doesn't. There are many higher-quality HOPA games out there with more gameplay hours for the same price, and a much more captivating storyline.

If you're a collector of HOPAs and really want to buy Frankenstein: Master of Death, I strongly suggest you wait until it goes on sale for a couple of dollars. To the general gaming public, I can't recommend this game at all.

Anyway, if you like Artifex Mundi, you'll probs like this game too.

reviewText:
Frankenstein: Master of Death is a hidden objects game where after receiving a letter of Victor Frankenstein, an old friend and a brilliant scientist that has managed to resurrect the dead you travel to his home to reveal a secret.

There are different kind of puzzles, mini games and tasks to find many objects from a list in the screen. In these ones, sometimes you must combine objects of the scene with objects of the inventory, so it adds a plus of difficulty in this kind of puzzles.

You can choose the difficulty between: easy and difficult but there is no difficult instead.

There is a hint button in a corner to help you. Depending on the level of difficulty, it refills quickest and tells you which are your next step.

You move around the different places using icon arrows on the screen. There is a map that indicates if there are things to do or there is nothing to do in these locations. It also teleports you to one location if you click on it, so its easy to move around and solve puzzles.

The different locations are drawn in high resolution and characters are well modeled in 3D. There are a lot of animations that helps to explain the story and pre rendered cut scenes

Music is quite good and enviroment sound are normal.

The game has achivements and trading cards and you could finish the game in few hours obtaning all of them.

These guys have learnt of their last games, and they are improved the overall quality of their new game.

As all these kind of games, it is a great entertainmentto play during an evening.

reviewText:
'Frankenstein: Master of Death' is a well designed adventure game which is nearly casual and has its growing pains, but is stands on a solid fundament.

Desc: You're a friend of Viktor Frankenstein who has written a letter to you that he is in need of your help immediately. You travel to the estate of Frankenstein to figure out what has happened. As one of the first scenes you will see the created creature of Frankenstein which is a revived dead body as it is always. Nothing new so far, but the story will not stay at this level of 	clichés. It will introduce another pawn into the story and explain why everything went wrong at the Frankenstein estate to end with a punch line.

Pros:
+ well designed artwork
+ feels like an adventure of the 90's
+ sometimes interesting puzzles
+ hint system
+ map (to jump to areas directly)
(+ steam achievements)

Cons:
- too much hidden object puzzles (there are more then 10 of them)
- 'key system' is over the time annoying and not very witty (to enter a door or other objects you will ALWAYS need 1/2/3/4 keys/amulets that are hidden somewhere)
- solutions are too easy, puzzles are too easy, game is straight linear (there are two modes you can choose, but the difference is only if the map will show whether you have completed a certain area or not and a downgraded hint system)
- the animation scenes are cute, but really not needed (I don't want/need to see everytime a screwdiver animation if I use it)
- soundtrack is a bit harsh without any great potential
- no voice of the main character (only some scenes have sound)
(- no demo)

Recommended, but only if it's on sale, because of the casual factor the game has.

5/10

reviewText:
Good entertainment for an afternoon

Jetdogs have a few hidden object titles on Steam and this is one of their best from the games I have played. It's an enjoyable romp through atmospheric scenes and puzzles that won't cause too many problems to solve.

In fact the puzzles are rather easy, thus this would be a great game for kids or beginners to the genre. Only one puzzle took me more than a few minutes (a tetrahedron, and even then it only took about 15 minutes), so I would have appreciated a more challenging experience. I played it on the harder level so It must be basically just a playthrough on the lower setting. In fact you are often told exactly what you need at a given time. For instance, when arriving at an impasse, you will be informed that a crowbar would be useful. As you pick up the crowbar very early on, there is absolutely no challenge in going to your inventory and then using it.

The music throughout is very good. Different classical pieces really add to the absorbing locations. The story itself makes sense and is reasonable for a casual HOG. The story held my interest and was a motivating factor in completing the game.

I enjoyed Frankenstein and it was a welcome break in between playing more traditional, tougher point and click adventure games.

reviewText:
Short version: 73%This is a beautiful and easy hidden object game that heavily depends on good player memory. It is recommended for those who want some new, yet not too different experience in this genre.

Long version:Frankenstein: Master of Death is the kind of hidden object game that tries to win buyers with its gorgeous visuals that look good on any store page. But, like many good-looking games, it lacks in gameplay: most puzzles last barely half a minute, and even the hidden object scenes are too desolate– albeit not bad– to provide any challenge. Most of the difficulty comes from the amount of backtracking, so I hope you have a decent memory.

The story uses Mary Shelley’s classic as sort of a loose frame to build upon, and creates a standard “rescue kidnapped woman” plot around it. Thankfully said plot barely makes any presence, which also means that the amount of voiced lines is low enough to not get on anyone’s nerves.

Overall, it is a pretty, decent, but quite forgettable game with nice visuals. Get it if you want to expand your library of hidden object games with playable quality.

reviewText:
How To Like - Frankenstein: Master of Death - Review

Short Version:
- Maybe Buy it On Sale & Only Play it On Hard Mode (as the game itself recommends)
- Expect a fun and short (couple of hours long) interactive Puzzle-play experience.
- Don't expect great story or characters you'll care to remember
- Seemingly illogical at times, but kept me enjoyably engaged until I finished the game - in one go.

Long Version:

WHEN MUST YOU PLAY THIS GAME -

I recommend - you play it - WHEN you're in the mood to take a break from long, intensive & content-heavy-games (which we love and must always go back to), and you're in the mood to play something just for fun - that'll massage your brain, in that almost-challenging-kind-of-way...

Also, while the Game is a HOG, the entire game isn't about finding hidden objects, in fact the HOG part of the game appears in the form of minigames within the game, absent which you're usually solving puzzles or collecting objects and putting them to use, which according to me was really fun - as it kept the game from becoming monotonous...Since the only other HOG i've played is Criminal Cases on FACEBOOK - I embarassingly admit - I'm fully aware of how quickly such games risk tiring you out...

WHEN MUST YOU NOT PLAY THIS GAME -

If you're expecting a story-driven experience - Do not play this game then! Because the story just feels like it's there for the sake of being there, flimsily attempting to hold the game together. Not meaning to be harsh, but I just felt like the backdrop and the base story - Visit Frankenstein who manages to resurrect the dead" - just had so much potential to make for an interesting plot and memorable characters.

WHAT COULD HAVE BEEN! -

Instead of playing an investigating friend that's trying to puzzle out how to save your friend from the resulting dangers of his experiments with death
date: the story could have been intelligently woven around Frankenstein himself. In other words a HOG that had the player traverse "the fragile border between life and death
recommended:
carrying out puzzling experiments and collecting important ingredients and samples - to concuct the solution for eternal life. If it had a solid story and a loveable character, it could have even been as something I'd love to see and gladly buy - when released as episodes.


ALL IN ALL THOUGH -

It's definitely a fun experience worth playing, or atleast a game you should give a shot - if on discount. It's a relatively short game that provides an experience which you'll enjoy, but not one which will stay with you after you'ved played it.

But I'll say this though, eventhough you'll scoff and complain at a few instances in the game, if you're into it - the game can keep you hooked and it's a fun experience to watch unravel. I was playing it with a friend by my side and even as a spectator - it kept him engaged to the end as well, just watching and shouting suggestions and ideas for solving the puzzles and obstacles the game presented, all the way till we finished it.

It also helps that the game has mini-cutscenes that show you actually using your objects from your inventory, on the objects to which their uses correspond to. Although couldn't help but raise an eyebrow, when I could break open a box with a crowbar which I had, but had to go through various obstacles to find a handle to use in order to open a glass cabinet.

... AAAAAND If I don't stop blabbering now, this review may just extend to being longer than this game. Forgive the dry humour - it's in good taste, eventhough if funny tasted good - that joke would taste like crap.

...Urrr so yea! I Totally recommend playing this game as not being a bad idea. I'm glad I did!

Disclaimer - This Review is subject to my fallible judgement & limited knowledge.

- Saad Merchant

reviewText:
Your friend Victor has reached out to you asking for help, but he has done so in a vague way. You must find out what ails your friend so you quickly go to where he is. You are to be met by the love of his life Elizabeth, but upon arrival a monster pulsing with electricity takes off with her, and closes the gate behind it. You will now have to find your way through this and many more puzzles as you try to unravel the mysteries surrounding not only this place but what your friend has been up to.

Maybe I'm getting better at these type of games, but I felt like this one was pretty short. After two hour and a half I saw the credits rolling, the rest are spent on getting the rest of the achievement and of course once again a twist right at the end. I wonder if any of these games will actually have a sequel? One of the few things I dislike about this game is when there were some items that seemed pretty important at the time that were one and done, but there were other items that definitely could have different uses that you just kept in your inventory forever. At the same time you would get to a point in the game where you are still toting around a lot of the reusable stuff that you have now gotten used to and magically it would disappear after you hit the limit or the usefulness was magically up.

Although the game was short I did enjoy the puzzle solving, and the different puzzles that were put in my way. I did notice that there were quite a few times where I felt like I was going between the exact two places to unlock something or retrieve an item. I know that you don't want to just have a room that is done one time through, but it seemed odd that to unlock this room you had to go to another room and then go back, unlock something, and then go back to that other room to unlock something there in turn.
At the end of the day this game definitely allows you to dip your foot into something that can definitely keep you occupied, and for the most part entertained. Is this a must have game, no, but its not a terrible game either. So if you're a fan of the genre, you might want to get it while it's on sale.


EDIT: Almost forgot to mention that right off the bat I ran into a problem where the game was crashed for no reason. And after doing some investigating, turned out the problem was on my end (thanks ESET!). Thankfully that was the last time I see it though.

I like these games for the puzzles (mini games), I would be happy with just them and no Hidden Objects and no story. Most of the time, the rest is fun too though. As is the case here.

The area the story takes place is rather large, a lot of different locations that aren't all within the same building.

It has fast travel by map, I blame tiredness/RL distractions for not being able to quite get where to go and what to do early on, when I mostly resorted to just using the hint for directions. Near the end I got a hang of things though. If you can remember what's where (and there's images of the locations on the map), you won't have any trouble fast jumping around the map.

The story is rather nice too.

There are few games where I don't turn the music off first thing, so I can't say anthing about that.

reviewText:
If you don't play many hidden object games, it might shock you to learn there's a huge amount of variance between them. Frankenstein is an excellent example of this, having a solid engine and slick visuals married to absolutely brain-dead gameplay. And that's not even that much of a knock against it, considering the trappings of the genre.

Frankenstein is, unsurprisingly, a re-telling of Mary Shelley's classic tale of science gone awry, just with more crests and crossbows to click on. In a strange twist (yes I am going to spoil the plot of a hidden object game, brace yourselves), Frankenstein is actually the hero, compelled to complete his heinous experiments by his partner and patron Igor. You play his friend, firmly invested in saving him from Igor and his monster, who looks remarkably like Raziel from Soul Reaver pre-jaw loss. The cutscenes are pretty well animated and the game actually has dynamic 3D models for many of the characters and creatures, which is a huge step up from its peers.

The gameplay is the customary hidden object scenes and simple puzzles, but taken to an infantile extreme. The hidden object scenes are absolutely huge, with some objects to find being nearly a quarter of the screen. Seriously, you could click at random and find all but the multi-part items, which usually just require pushing a button, using a knife on a rope, or assembling something. The challenge here is way, way down from other hidden object games, and is brought back up in aggravating fashion by tons of backtracking and an absurd number of crests. Seriously, I think there are maybe three keys in the game compared to the three dozen crests you have to collect to open up all the rooms of the mansion.

It's a very clean-looking product, with no technical hitches and all the quality-of-life elements of a modern hidden object game. It's just not very engaging, mostly because of the poor difficulty balance. If you got it for pennies like I did it's worth a try, but I can hardly recommend it at full price.

- The story has a Re-Animator vibe to it, kind of dark for a game of this nature and pretty cool.
- Hidden Object Scenes often have puzzles integrated into them directly that you must solve to collect an item. These are similar puzzles to what you see in other HOGs, but I enjoyed that slight twist. It also has standalone puzzles that are sometimes similar to what's in the HOG scene.

The bad:
- The game itself is very short (achieved 100% with 2.7 hours), and
- the majority of that time is spent collecting excessive amounts of tools and items, and backtracking through scenes to use them. I know this is a common tactic in many HOGs, but the in this game, it seems like for every one item or tool you use to unlock a chest or new area, you discover two to three new ones.
- Because it requires so many items to complete, it does get overwhelming trying to remember the exact location of every single interactive object in each scene. Probably not too difficult on Easy difficulty, but if you're playing on Expert, you will probably be missing destructible walls and lost items left and right. Often times you'll wind up advancing five or six scenes to collect an object, and then spend ten or more minutes trying to remember and then find the location that it's to be used.
- That's confounded by the fact that the game's locations become a blur. You can theoretically divide it up between three main indoor areas (which are subsequently each divided up between three to six sub-rooms), and then linear outdoor areas that conjoin them. While it's fairly easy to keep track of the outdoor areas, I would find myself oftentimes wandering around one house for several minutes just to realize the object I was looking for was actually in a different house altogether.
- Finally, the puzzles themselves are just way too easy and require very little thought.

Overall, although it starts off on a strong foot, it quickly devolves into an extremely repetitive (and oft frustrating) experience that became a chore to finish.
I would recommend any number of other HOGs before this one.

Got this on sale for 50 cents, so I can't really complain, but for $5 this game would be a big disappointment. Think of all the things that tend to be tedious about hidden object adventure games: lots of pointless back-and-forth between locations, stiff 3D animated cut scenes, tasks that demand exactly the right tool even though you have plenty of stuff that should be able to solve the problem... this game had it all.

That last issue was especially aggravating in this game. It's annoying when you use an item and it vanishes from your inventory when any rational person would keep it around, and that happens here with a torch and a bucket, both of which would come in handy later. You do get to keep quite a few items for most of the game, like a knife, a crowbar, and a screwdriver.

But for example, when you find a cabinet with a missing handle and a cracked glass door, you can't use your crowbar to shatter the already broken glass to get the fishing pole you can clearly see in reach. You have to run around for ten minutes until you find that missing handle. At one point I was confronted with boards nailed across a doorway. I couldn't use the crowbar because the boards were nailed from the other side, which is dumb enough, but I also couldn't use the hacksaw in my inventory to saw through the boards. No explanation for that. The game forced me to wait until I found an ax before I could get through those boards.

That kind of thing happened over and over again. Along with another pet peeve of mine that shows up in too many of these games: you're supposedly racing to rescue your friends, but your character is too squeamish to touch cobwebs or coal with his bare hands, so you have to go find gloves and tools. It breaks any suspension of disbelief the story managed to work up.

I play this type of game partly to admire the illustrations, and this had nice art. But in some little areas, the second I clicked on the items to add them to my inventory, the scene vanished, and I wasn't able to click on it and see it again, which seems like a waste after they went to the trouble to illustrate those areas.

The story for some reason makes Igor out to be the villain rather than Viktor, but this change doesn't seem to amount to much. It appears to be set in the original story's time period, but there are weird anachronisms-- at one point, you find and search a Volkswagon Beetle! The hidden object scenes and puzzles were very easy.

For one or two bucks this game would be okay, but I think anyone who pays more than that would be disappointed.

reviewText:
There are worse HOGs than Frankenstein: Master of Death, but it still isn't very good.  The English translation is mostly passable, but frequently stilted, and some of the voice actors are less than convincing.  The gameplay is very linear; despite a few forks in the map, you will work through each puzzle and unlock each gate in exactly the designed order -- you will never have a few potential options.  The HO scenes are brief and not particularly challenging.

The pseudo-historical setting is even more anachronistic than usual.  Your character arrives on the scene in a horse-drawn carriage, but later uncovers a Volkswagen Beetle... presumably just because the creators already had an HO scene set in a car that they wanted to use.  The Frankenstein mythos is predictably abused as well.  The original book is completely lost, and the game refers more to the various film adaptations, but with Igor the lab assistant transformed from a deformed wretch into a power-mad nobleman with a penchant for moustache-twirling villainous monologues.

This might satisfy the itch to play an HO game, but there are plenty of superior options out there.

You have to reuse tools and objects you found a long time ago, and also use new tools on old objects you discovered a long time ago, which does mean some back-tracking but it's not that much of a problem, and really ties the entire game together and makes it feel solid.

Hunting down keys nonstop basically makes Frankenstein: MoD a huge fetch-quest, which isn't a good thing. But how else can you design this sort of game without it consisting of SOME back-tracking? The voice acting is below par, but only in the non-cutscene dialogue sequences. Inside cutscenes the characters have better voice acting funny enough, though even out of them it's not THAT bad, just a bit choppy and some of Igor's lines almost sounded sarcastic when they were supposed to be serious. I love how the game removes items from your inventory when you're officially done using it, like for example I got a crowbar at the beginning of the game and opened things up with it throughout the entire game to the very last 20 minutes, but the last time I needed to use it it left my inventory afterwards. This created a cool sense of progression as by the time I got down to the final task in the entire game, I only had one item in my inventory, it almost made it more dramatic and intense.

I only have a couple complaints about Frankenstein: MoD. The first one is the fact that some parts of the game are incredibly specific, but mind you it only happens like three times; most of the time it's pretty easy to see where to progress (I played in Hard Difficulty, if that means anything? Not sure what Easy did but Hard was easy enough). But these few spots had things that were way too specific and basically required the use of a hint, and if you're trying to do a hint-less run, you would probably need prior knowledge of the game. My second and final complaint is a tiny picky problem I have with the end of the game: you start to pop Steam achievements for, say, never skipping an I-Spy mini-game right after the last one is completed, but the game isn't necessarily completed. So as long as you don't check the achievements it probably wouldn't be a problem but I popped it, looked at it's description, and saw that I completed my final I-Spy mission thus basically telling me the game only had a few minutes left. I don't know, it was just a weird way to end the game, knowing exactly that this is the end.

But aside from those small problems Frankenstein: MoD was a pretty good game. The reason I only gave it a 7/10 after saying all these positives about it is because of how mundane the actual gameplay can be. It really is just a huge fest quest hidden under easy puzzles and pretty art. But it did manage to hold my attention for a good 2.5 hours, which is rare nowadays, so there must be something about it that most games don't have.

7.4/10
